TAXONOMIC CLASS.content: TAXONOMIC CLASS: Fine, mixed, superactive, frigid Typic Endoaquolls

TYPICAL PEDON.content:
TYPICAL PEDON:  Bolack silt loam, native grass (colors are for moist soil unless otherwise noted).
Oi--3 inches to 0; peat (0 to 4 inches thick)
A--0 to 10 inches; black (10YR 2/1) silt loam, dark gray (10YR 4/1) dry; weak medium subangular blocky structure; slightly hard, friable, slightly sticky and slightly plastic; many very fine roots; many fine irregular pores; neutral (pH 7.0); clear smooth boundary. (7 to 15 inches thick)
Bg1--10 to 14 inches; dark gray (10YR 4/1) silty clay loam, light gray (10YR 7/1) dry; many fine distinct dark yellowish brown (10YR 4/6) redox concentrations; weak medium subangular blocky structure; hard, firm, sticky and plastic; many fine and very fine roots; many fine and medium tubular pores; neutral (pH 7.0); clear smooth boundary.
Bg2--14 to 25 inches; grayish brown (10YR 5/2) clay; light gray (10YR 7/2) dry; many medium distinct dark yellowish brown (10YR 4/4) moist redox concentrations; moderate medium and coarse subangular blocky structure; very hard, extremely firm, very sticky and very plastic; common fine and medium roots; common fine tubular pores; slightly alkaline (pH 7.4); gradual smooth boundary.
Bg3--25 to 44 inches; light brownish gray (10YR 6/2) clay; light gray (10YR 7/2) dry; many large distinct dark yellowish brown (10YR 4/4) moist redox concentrations; moderate medium subangular blocky structure; very hard, extremely firm, very sticky and very plastic; few fine and medium roots; few fine tubular pores; slightly alkaline (pH 7.6); gradual smooth boundary. (Combined thickness of the Bg horizons is 9 to 50 inches.)
Cg--44 to 60 inches; light gray (10YR 6/1) gravelly clay, white (10YR 8/1); many large distinct dark yellowish brown (10YR 4/4) moist redox concentrations; massive; very hard, extremely firm, very sticky and very plastic; 20 percent pebbles; slightly effervescent; moderately alkaline (pH 8.0).

TYPE LOCATION.content: TYPE LOCATION:  Lake County, Montana; 1,800 feet east and 1,850 feet south of the NW corner of sec. 1, T. 18 N., R. 20 W.

RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS.content:
RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS:
Soil temperature - 43 to 47 degrees F.
Moisture control section - between 4 and 12 inches.
Mollic epipedon thickness - 7 to 20 inches.
Control section - 35 to 60 percent clay.
Depth to seasonal water table - 12 to 24 inches.
Some pedons have a thin 1 to 4 inch surface layer of peat.
A horizon - Value:  3, 4, or 5 dry; 2 or 3 moist
Clay content:  18 to 27 percent
Reaction:  pH 6.6 to 7.3
Bg1 horizon - Value:  5, 6 or 7 dry; 3 or 4 moist
Chroma:  1 or 2
Texture:  silty clay or silty clay loam
Redoximorphic features: few to many 10YR 4/4, 10YR 4/6 redox concentrations
Clay content:  27 to 45 percent
Reaction:  pH 6.6 to 7.3
Bg2 & Bg3 horizons - Hue:  5Y, 2.5Y, or 10YR
Value:  5, 6, or 7 dry; 4, 5 or 6 moist
Chroma:  0, 1 or 2
Redoximorphic features:  few to many 10YR 4/4, 10YR 4/6 redox concentrations; none to common 10YR 6/1 redox depletions
Texture:  clay or silty clay
Clay content:  40 to 60 percent
Reaction:  pH 7.4 to 7.8
Cg horizon - Hue:  5Y, N, 2.5Y, or 10YR
Value:  6, 7, or 8 dry; 4, 5, or 6 moist
Chroma:  0, 1, or 2
Redoximorphic features:  few to many 10YR 4/4, 10YR 4/6 redox concentrations; none to common 10YR 6/1 redox depletions
Texture:  clay or silty clay
Clay content:  40 to 60 percent
Rock fragments:  0 to 25 percent pebbles
Reaction:  pH 7.4 to 8.4

COMPETING SERIES.content:
COMPETING SERIES:
There are no competing series.

GEOGRAPHIC SETTING.content:
GEOGRAPHIC SETTING:
Landform - flood plains
Elevation - 2,500 to 3,300 feet
Slope - 0 to 2 percent
Parent material - alluvium
Climate - long, cold winters; moist springs; warm summers
Mean annual precipitation - 12 to 18 inches
Mean annual air temperature - 41 to 45 degrees F.
Frost-free period - 100 to 120 days

USE AND VEGETATION.content: DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY:  Poorly drained; slow permeability.

DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT.content: USE AND VEGETATION:  Bolack soils are used mainly for rangeland, pastureland, hayland, and wildlife habitat.  The potential native vegetation is mainly tufted hairgrass, mannagrasses, northern reedgrass, tall sedges, and tall brushes.

REGIONAL OFFICE.content: DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT:  Bolack soils are of small extent in the mountain valleys of western Montana.

ORIGIN.section: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE
ORIGIN.content: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE:  Bozeman, Montana.

REMARKS.content: SERIES ESTABLISHED:  Lake County, Montana, 1991; proposed in Lake County, Montana, 1986.  Bolack is a coined name.
